column1: == Economy ==
Among Honduran cities
column2: La Ceiba is the second most important port town after Puerto Cortés. Its economy is made up of mostly commerce and agriculture. Pineapple is the city's major export. Its largest producer is the Standard Fruit Company
column3: a subsidiary of the Dole Food Company
column4: which operates throughout northern Honduras and is based in La Ceiba.

column1: Tourism also plays a large role in the city's economy (see below). Since its development in the late 20th century
column2: the La Ceiba seaport has played an ever-increasing role in the economy of the city. This port represents a vital economic artery to La Ceiba's growing tourist industry. Additionally
column3: the La Ceiba sea port is home to one of the finest boatyards in the north west Caribbean (According to Western Caribbean Cruising Guidebook). Known as the La Ceiba Shipyard
column4: this company offers a complete group of marine services for all types of seagoing vessels.

column1: == Education ==

column2: which is considered the main street of the city. Instituto Manuel Bonilla is the largest public High School in the city
column3: with over 5

column1: There are also many private schools in La Ceiba. Several private bilingual education schools offer instruction in both Spanish and English. Most of these offer a Honduran Bachillerato Diploma (equivalent of High school diploma)
column2: while Mazapan School offers a US-accredited High School diploma as well. These schools usually offer grades 1 – 11/12
column3: with some offering pre-school education.

column1: == Tourism ==
La Ceiba has long been known as the tourism capital of Honduras
column2: due to its proximity to the beach
column3: active night life
column4: and a variety of parks and recreational areas in and around the city. Another factor contributing to the city's tourism is the city port. It provides ferry services to the Bay Islands/Islas de la Bahia in the Caribbean. Ferries from this port also offer daily service to the main islands of Útila and Roatán.

column1: The area around La Ceiba has many parks and natural reserves. Its most recognised natural area is the Pico Bonito (Beautiful Peak) National park. This park's most recognised feature
column2: Pico Bonito on the Nombre de Dios mountain range
column3: is 2435 meters high and provides a back drop for the city. The Cangrejal River
column4: popular for its Class III-IV river rafting
column5: borders the eastern edge of the city and the Cuero and Salado Wildlife refuges with its wild manatees is located a few miles to the west of the city.

column1: Semana Santa (Holy Week) is one of the city's busiest tourist seasons. During this week tourists from all over the country flock to the city to enjoy its sun
column2: beach
column3: and very active night life during that week during Carnaval before Ash Wednesday.

column1: The busiest tourist season by far is the week leading up to the internationally renowned "Gran Carnaval Internacional de La Ceiba" which is a citywide celebration in honour of the city's patron saint
column2: St. Isidore (San Isidro). During the week leading up to the third Saturday in May
column3: many neighbourhoods have smaller celebrations in one or a couple of their streets. On Saturday afternoon the big parade with elaborate floats takes place along Avenida San Isidro
column4: the city's main thoroughfare. After the parade
column5: the locals and tourists all have a celebration along that same road

column1: == Transportation ==

There were trains running through La Ceiba to bring the bananas from the plantations but they are not active any longer although traces of the old railroad tracks can still be seen. Nowadays a 3 km-long city rail line still works and
column2: in the nearby village of La Unión
column3: it exists a short tourist railway to Cuero y Salado National Park.

column1: Buses and taxis make up most of the public transportation in the city
column2: with numerous buses serving almost every available route in the city. Taxi-cabs are numerous in the city
column3: costing as little as L.25.00 (just over $1.25 as of 2013) for destinations within the city limits.

column1: The pier to the east of the city offers transportation via ferry to 2 of the 3 major islands that make up Islas de la Bahia; Roatan and Utila. The Golosón International Airport to the west of town offers flights to the other major cities in the country as well as other towns in the Mosquitia Region of Honduras in the east. This airport is hub to Aerolíneas Sosa. There is also a bus station just west of the city centre though some buses also run from their own terminals.
